item.title: Making The Case For Emmett Johnson In The Heisman Conversation
item.dc:creator: Gavyn Nylander
item.description:
Code 
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

fb <- read_csv("EJHeisman.csv") |> 
  clean_names() |> 
  mutate(player_team = paste0(player, ", ", team))

heisman <- read_csv("oldheisman.csv")

head(heisman)
# A tibble: 6 × 19
   Year Player   Team  Conf      G RuAtt RuYds `RuY/A`  RuTD `RuY/G` ReRec ReYds
  <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1  2025 Emmett … Nebr… Big …    12   251  1451     5.8    12    121.    46   370
2  2015 Derrick… Alab… SEC      15   395  2219     5.6    28    148.    11    91
3  2009 Mark In… Alab… SEC      14   271  1658     6.1    17    118.    32   334
4  2005 Reggie … USC   Pac-…    13   200  1740     8.7    16    134.    37   478
5  1999 Ron Day… Wisc… Big …    11   303  1834     6.1    19    167.     1     9
6  1998 Ricky W… Texas Big …    11   361  2124     5.9    27    193.    24   262
# ℹ 7 more variables: `ReY/R` <dbl>, ReTD <dbl>, `ReY/G` <dbl>, Plays <dbl>,
#   Yds <dbl>, Avg <dbl>, TD <dbl>
Code 
yards <- heisman |> 
  filter(
    Yds >= 1821
  ) |> 
  mutate(Player = gsub("*", "", Player, fixed=TRUE))


ej <- heisman |> 
  filter(
    Player == "Emmett Johnson"
  )


ggplot() + geom_bar(data=yards, aes(x= reorder(Player,Yds), weight=Yds), fill="grey") +
  geom_bar(data=ej, aes(x= reorder(Player,Yds), weight=Yds), fill="red") + 
  labs(
    x=" ", 
    y="Total Yards", 
    title="Does Emmett Johnson Compare to Past Heisman Winners?", 
    subtitle="Total yards show how Johnson's 2025 season can measure up to the same level as past \nwinning running backs. ", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Gavyn Nylander"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )
Code 
top100 <- fb |> 
  top_n(100, wt=-rk)

top10 <- fb |> 
  top_n(10, wt=-rk)

emmett <- top10 |> 
  filter(player == "Emmett Johnson")

love <- top10 |> 
  filter(player == "Jeremiyah Love")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=top100, aes(x=ru_yds, y=ru_y_a), color = "grey") + 
  geom_point(data=top10, aes(x=ru_yds, y=ru_y_a), color = "blue") +
  geom_point(data=emmett, aes(x=ru_yds, y=ru_y_a), color = "#d00000") +
  geom_point(data=love, aes(x=ru_yds, y=ru_y_a), color = "#0c2340") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=emmett, 
    aes(x=ru_yds, y=ru_y_a, label=player)
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=love, 
    aes(x=ru_yds, y=ru_y_a, label=player)
  ) +
  labs(
    x="Total Rushing Yards", 
    y="Yards Per Attempt", 
    title="Comparing Emmett Johnson's Standing Amoung Top Rushers", 
    subtitle="Comparing total rushing yards and yards per attempt to highlight Johnson efficency against \nother running backs.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Gavyn Nylander"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )
Code 
top10 <- fb |> 
  top_n(10, wt=-rk)

ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=top10, 
    aes(y=reorder(player_team, re_yds), x=ru_yds, xend=re_yds),size = 3,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
     x="Rushing vs.Recieving Yards", 
    y=" ",
    title="Rushing Yards vs. Recieving Yards in the Top 10", 
    subtitle = "Emmett proves that he is an all around athlete with his <span style = 'color:green;'>rushing yards</span> and his <span style = 'color:red;'>recieving yards</span> telling a story of his various plays.",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | Gavyn Nylander"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(), 
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )

item.title: The Michael Phelps Legacy: Showing That Longevity Creates an Athletic Advantage
item.dc:creator: Gavyn Nylander
item.description:
When you hear about Olympic swimming, one name always comes to mind: Michael Phelps. Since the retirement of the legend, another name has been brought up in conversation: Caeleb Dressel. Both have won many medals in their field and have made many contributions to the sport. Yet one key factor sets them apart, it’s not just the medals or their speed, but the duration of how long they have participated in the Olympics for. 

 

In 2000, Phelps competed in his first Olympics at the age of 15. Dressel, however, is much newer to the Olympic stage competing in his first games in 2016, showing the wide difference in the duration of their Olympic careers. 

 

Phelps background highlights how continued involvement in a sport can have its benefits. Years at the highest level provides more opportunities to develop the competitive spirit that it takes to be successful on a global stage.

Code 
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(gt)
library(ggbeeswarm)

swim <- read_csv("SPMC350-Data3 - CaelebvMichaelData.csv")

usa <- swim |> 
  filter(Nat == "USA") |> 
  group_by(Swimmer) |> 
  tally()

michael <- usa |> 
  filter(Swimmer == "Michael Phelps")

caeleb <- usa |> 
  filter(Swimmer == "Caeleb Dressel")

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=usa, aes(x=reorder(Swimmer, n), weight=n), fill = "grey") +
   geom_bar(data=michael, aes(x=reorder(Swimmer, n), weight=n), fill = "blue") +
   geom_bar(data=caeleb, aes(x=reorder(Swimmer, n), weight=n), fill = "orange") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x=" ", 
    y="Olympic Apperances",
    title="A Lap Around The Pool For Phelps", 
    subtitle="Athletic ability is more than medals, after 6 Olympic apperances Phelps is showing \nthat the longer you're in it the more sucessful you can become", 
    caption="Source: Olympedia | Gavyn Nylander"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )

Since Dressel is still in the middle of his career, his points on the chart are more recent. Phelps points span over a longer period of time, showing how dominate he has been through his different competitive periods. 

 

Dressel has shown that he should be held to the same level as Phelps, breaking his record in the 100-meter butterfly. However, Phelps’s reaction times demonstrate that not only is he still able to compete, but that he is able to surpass the competition. 

 

The 50-meter reaction times of Phelps and Dressel show how close their performances are. Both athletes maintain the same level of speed right from the start, despite there being a gap in the levels between these two. But Phelps has the advantage of his reaction times, demonstrating that with more years under him, Phelps has a bit of an athletic advantage.

Code 
swimmers <- read_csv("SPMC350-Data - CaelebvMichaelData.csv")

set.seed(1234)

fixedswim <- swimmers |> separate(Final, into=c("Final", "Place"), sep="\\(") |> 
  mutate(Place=gsub(")", "", Place))

split <- fixedswim |> 
  filter(Event == "Freestyle Relay") |> 
  filter(is.na(Reaction) == FALSE)


michael <- split |> 
  filter(Swimmer == "Michael Phelps") 

  
caeleb <- split |> 
  filter(Swimmer == "Caeleb Dressel")


ggplot() +
  geom_beeswarm(data=split, aes(x=Reaction, y=`50m`), color="grey") +
  geom_beeswarm(data=michael, aes(x=Reaction, y=`50m`), color="blue") +
  geom_beeswarm(data=caeleb, aes(x=Reaction, y=`50m`), color="orange") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=michael, 
    aes(x=Reaction, y=`50m`, label=Swimmer)) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=caeleb, 
    aes(x=Reaction, y=`50m`, label=Swimmer)) + 
  labs(
    title="Two Generations, One Sprint: More experience wins it all", 
    subtitle="While Phelps and Dressel stay in the same range in their 50m time, Phelps continues \nto prove why he is the most decorated swimmer based on his reaction time.", 
    caption="Source: Olympedia | Gavyn Nylander"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )

The difference becomes clearer when you consider the accomplishments of each individual athlete. Phelps has competed at the top level for six Olympic games, where Dressel has only competed in three. Having competed on this stage for so long shows how much experience and dedication can impact an athlete’s career.

 

Every Olympics gives these athletes more races, relays, finals, and opportunities to improve with each additional event. Phelps has had years to train and compete for 16 years, which is shown in Phelps extensive medal collection. 

  

There is no doubt that with the training, Dressel could out compete Phelps in the future, as he could continue to break more records and earn more medals. Phelps’s career shows that being one of the greats requires the hard work and dedication that Phelps has put in over the years of his Olympic career.  

Code 
medals <- read_csv("SPMC350-Data3 - CaelebvMichaelData.csv")

compmedals <- medals |> 
  select(Swimmer, Gold, Silver, Bronze, Total) |> 
  filter(Total >= 6)

compmedals |> gt() |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Most Medals Won by Olympic Swimmers",
    subtitle = "16 years of training shows why Michael Phelps is considered one of the greats"
  )|> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Gavyn Nylander  |  **Source:** Olympedia")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(4)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=13)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "blue"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Swimmer == "Michael Phelps") 
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "orange"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Swimmer == "Caeleb Dressel")
  )
Most Medals Won by Olympic Swimmers
16 years of training shows why Michael Phelps is considered one of the greats
Swimmer Gold Silver Bronze Total
Michael Phelps 23 3 2 28
Mark Spitz 9 1 1 11
Jenny Thompson 8 3 1 12
Matt Biondi 8 2 1 11
Katie Ledecky 7 3 0 10
Ryan Lochte 6 3 3 12
Gary Hall, Jr. 5 3 2 10
Caeleb Dressel 9 1 0 10
Kristin Otto 6 0 0 6
Amy Van Dyken 6 0 0 6
By: Gavyn Nylander | Source: Olympedia

When comparing these two athletes medal counts, the difference between them becomes even more obvious. Phelps has won more medals than any other swimmer. With 28 medals showing what years of hard work looks like. 

 

The data illustrates how long-term commitment in sports has positive outcomes for athletes. This is something that is shown in other sports, not just in the swimming world. Years of dedication to a sport contributes to building a legacy that inspires other athletes to follow long and hope to be a part of that same legacy someday.
